data.title: A nation treasure elicited in a historical building
data.text: The museum is quite small, located in an old bank building near the Tallahassee Capitol. You will be amazed at their collection-- perhaps one of the most unique and best in the nation.

data.title: Enjoying a walk through history!
data.text: We had the opportunity to experience a great collection of history on a guide tour thought the musuem.  During the tour we were given specific information regard the historcal items.  I like all of the displays and the quaintness of the building.  Some of the displays and the narration really provide a great account of the past.

data.title: CLOSED
data.text: when we got there on Friday 10am  we found a typed paper taped to the glass that stated limited summer hours Wed- Fri  9 am -2 pm.  The door was locked and nobody was there.

data.title: Go to the Black Archives Research Center and Museum and learn your history
data.text: We try to annually visit this museum and attend the events held during the Emancipation week. We travel in from CT and always enjoy the programs offered at this museum.

data.title: A real eye-opener
data.text: So much information and detail. A great record of history in the South. Some of the displays were shocking but all were accurate.

data.title: Little Gem of a Museum
data.text:
SOUTHEAST REGIONAL BLACK ARCHIVES RESEARCH CENTER AND MUSEUM
219 Appalachia Parkway, Union Bank Tallahassee, FL 32307 850-561-2603
Located in Historic Carnegie Library at Florida A&M University, Tallahassee, 32307
(850) 599-3020    9:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m. Monday-Friday    Free Admission

This is a little gem of a museum of the black history and culture that has existed within 
the culture and history of white America.  It is well done, extensive, and very 
representative.  There are about five rooms containing artifacts from the previous eras:  
old dolls, iron slave collars, balls and chains, lists of slaves for sale and their 
prices, photographs, newspapers, KKK documents, etc.  Staff are very cordial.

This museum probably gets few visitors because of it's location off the beaten track.  
You won't just stumble onto it.  You have to look for it to find it.  And there is no 
parking in the immediate vicinity except for handicapped parking and we are told that 
parking tickets are given out to anyone parking illegally.

All visitors are required to secure a visitors parking decal from Parking Services located at 2400 Wahnish Way, south of the baseball stadium.  Parking Services is located in the same building as the FAMU Police Department and Physical Plant Operations.  The telephone number to Parking Services is 850-561-2204.   There is a parking building somewhere a few blocks from the museum.
